content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far away, there lived a young prince who had everything a prince could wish for—golden carriages, a grand castle, and servants to attend to his every need.
Yet, despite all his riches, the prince was unhappy. He longed to find a true princess, one who was kind, gentle, and of royal blood.
He searched high and low, traveling to distant lands and meeting many young ladies, but none of them seemed quite right. Some were too proud, others too vain, and a few simply did not have the
delicate nature he believed a true princess should possess. One stormy evening, as rain lashed against the castle windows and thunder rumbled in the distance, there came a knock at the
castle gate. The old king, curious about who would be out on such a wild night, ordered the guard to open the door.
Standing before them was a young woman, soaked to the skin, her hair dripping with rainwater. She was shivering and looked utterly exhausted.
"Please," she said in a soft voice, "I am a princess, traveling through your kingdom. Might I seek shelter here for the night?" The queen, who was just as eager as the prince to find a true
princess, eyed the young woman skeptically. "A princess, you say?" she asked. "How can we be sure?" The young woman nodded politely. "I understand your doubt, Your Majesty.
But I assure you, I am of royal blood." The queen, though still uncertain, decided to put the young woman to the test. She had a plan—a clever way to determine if this stranger was truly a princess.
Without saying a word, the queen ordered her servants to prepare a bed for their guest. But this was no ordinary bed.
The servants stacked twenty mattresses one atop the other, and beneath them, they placed a single, tiny pea. When the bed was ready, the queen led the young woman to the chamber.
"Here is your bed for the night," she said. "I do hope you sleep well." The young woman, grateful for the shelter, climbed into the towering bed.
She pulled the blankets up to her chin and closed her eyes, eager to rest after her long journey. But as she lay there, she could not find a comfortable position.
Something beneath the mattresses felt hard and lumpy, keeping her awake. She tossed and turned, trying to ignore the strange discomfort, but no matter how she lay, she could not fall asleep.
The next morning, the queen and the prince came to see how their guest had fared. The young woman looked tired, with dark circles under her eyes. "How did you sleep, my dear?"
the queen asked, though she already knew the answer. The young woman sighed. "I must confess, I did not sleep well at all. There was something hard in the bed, and I could not get comfortable.
It was as if I were lying on a stone!" The queen and the prince exchanged a knowing glance. Only a true princess, with the most delicate and sensitive skin, would have felt a single pea beneath
twenty mattresses. There could be no doubt—this young woman was indeed a real princess. Overjoyed, the prince stepped forward and took her hand.
"Then you must stay with us," he said warmly. "For you are the princess I have been searching for." And so, the prince and the princess were married in a grand ceremony, with all the nobles of the
kingdom in attendance. The pea, which had played such an important role in their story, was placed in the royal museum, where it can still be seen to this day.
And as for the princess, she lived happily ever after, proving that true royalty is not just about crowns and castles, but about kindness, grace, and a heart that is pure.
